subsection.title: The Natural Logarithmic Function
subsection.p: The base ee\thinspace logarithm of a number x, or \log_ e {(x)}, is called the natural logarithmnatural logarithm of x and is denoted by \ln {(x)}.

assemblage.title: The Natural Logarithm
assemblage.p: The natural logarithm is the logarithm base e. \blert{\ln {(x)} = \log_{e}{(x)}, ~~~~ x\gt 0}

subsection.p: The natural logarithm of x is the exponent to which e must be raised to produce x. For example, the natural logarithm of 10, or \ln {(10)}, is the solution of the equation e^y = 10 You can verify on your calculator that e^{\alert{2.3}} ~~ \approx 10 ~~ \text{ or } ~~ \ln {(10)} \approx \alert{2.3} In general, natural logs obey the same conversion equations that work for logs to other bases.

subsection.title: Exponential Growth and Decay

aside.p: \alert{\text{[TK]}}~~To review exponential growth, see Section 7.1.5 of the textbook.

subsection.p: For instance, consider a colony of bacteria that grows according to the formula P(t) = 100 \cdot \alert{3^t} We can express this function in the form P(t) = 100 \cdot \alert{e^{kt}} if we set 3 = e^k ~ \text{ or } ~ k = \ln {(3)} \approx 1.0986 Thus, the growth law for the colony of bacteria can be written P(t) \approx 100 \cdot e^{1.0986t} By graphing both functions on your calculator, you can verify that P(t) = 100 \cdot 3^t~~~\text{and}~~~P(t) = 100 \cdot e^{1.0986t} are just two ways of writing the same function.

statement.p: From 1990 to 2000, the population of Clark County, Nevada, grew by 6.4\% per year. ~\alert{\text{[TK]}}~~

ol.li: What was the growth factor for the population of Clark County from 1990 to 2000? If the population of Clark County was 768,000 in 1990, write a formula for the population t years later.

li.p: The growth factor was b = 1 + r = 1.064. The population t years later was P(t) = 768,000 (1.064)^t
We use the formula P(t) = P_0 \cdot e^{kt}, where e^k = 1.064. Solving for k, we find k = \ln {(1.064)} = 0.062 so P(t) = 768,000 e^{0.062t}.

li.p: Suppose you keep \$1000 in an account that pays 8% interest. How much is the amount A after 1 year if the interest is compounded twice a year?
